nodes.text: If a person is induced to say or do something contrary to a private opinion, they will tend to change that private opinion to align with the overt behavior, and the larger the external inducement beyond the minimum needed, the smaller the opinion change
Prior studies (Janis and King; Kelman) reported that forced public advocacy can produce private opinion change, with mixed findings about the effect of reward magnitude

Assumption from cognitive dissonance theory: magnitude of dissonance equals sum of dissonances divided by sum of dissonances plus consonances, so greater external justification (larger reward) reduces dissonance

Method: Laboratory experiment with 71 male introductory psychology students performing two boring tasks then being induced to tell a waiting student the tasks were enjoyable; conditions were Control (no inducement), One Dollar inducement, and Twenty Dollars inducement

Method details: Tasks made uniformly boring, experimenter setup created plausible cover story, induced subjects to tell a waiting confederate the tasks were enjoyable, taped the conversation, and later interviewed subjects with four rating questions and debriefed them
Design and sample used for analysis: after excluding 11 Ss for suspicion or noncompliance, analysis used 20 subjects per condition (Control, One Dollar, Twenty Dollars)

Result: On the interview question 'How enjoyable the tasks were' (primary dissonance-relevant measure), One Dollar subjects rated tasks significantly more enjoyable (mean +1.35) than Control (mean -0.45), p approx 0.02
Result: Twenty Dollar subjects rated task enjoyment near Control (mean -0.05), not significantly different from Control and significantly lower than One Dollar condition (difference p approx 0.03)
Result: On the learning question (unrelated to the induced statement) there were negligible differences among conditions, supporting specificity of the effect to dissonance-relevant content

Evidence against alternative explanation (self-rehearsal/improvisation): taped conversations were transcribed and rated blind on five dimensions; ratings show Twenty Dollar subjects were slightly higher or similar, so One Dollar subjects did not rehearse or persuade more

Claim: The pattern of results matches the cognitive dissonance prediction that induced opinion change occurs and is greatest when external justification is minimal (One Dollar) and reduced when external justification is larger (Twenty Dollars)

Conclusion: Experimental findings strongly corroborate the tested derivations of cognitive dissonance theory regarding forced compliance and the inverse relation between reward magnitude and opinion change
Limitation: Eleven subjects were excluded due to suspicion, refusal, or noncompliance which could affect generalizability and interpretation
Claim: Alternative dissonance-reduction routes such as magnifying perceived scientific importance showed only weak differences and cannot fully account for the main effect
